t: Jeremiah 1
The*p words of Jeremiah, the son of Hilkiah, one of the priests who were in Anathoth in the land of Benjamin,
to whom the word of the Lord*s came in the days of Josiah the son of Amon, king of Judah, in the thirteenth year of his reign.

It came also in the days of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah, king of Judah, and until the end of the eleventh year of Zedekiah, the son of Josiah, king of Judah, until the captivity of Jerusalem in the fifth month.
The Call of Jeremiah
Now*p the word of the Lord*s came to me, saying,
“Before*pn I formed you in the womb I knew you, and*ln before you were born I consecrated you; I*ln appointed you a prophet to the nations.”
Then*p I said, “Ah, Lord God!*s Behold, I do not know how to speak, for I am only a youth.”
But the Lord*s said to me, “Do*pn not say, ‘I am only a youth’; for*ln to all to whom I send you, you shall go, and*ln whatever I command you, you shall speak.
Do*ln not be afraid of them, for*ln I am with you to deliver you, declares*l the Lord.”*s
Then*p the Lord*s put out his hand and touched my mouth. And the Lord*s said to me, “Behold,*pn I have put my words in your mouth.
See,*ln I have set you this day over nations and over kingdoms, to*ln pluck up and to break down, to*ln destroy and to overthrow, to*ln build and to plant.”
And*p the word of the Lord*s came to me, saying, “Jeremiah, what do you see?” And I said, “I see an almond branch.”
Then the Lord*s said to me, “You have seen well, for I am watching over my word to perform it.”
The*p word of the Lord*s came to me a second time, saying, “What do you see?” And I said, “I see a boiling pot, facing away from the north.”
Then the Lord*s said to me, “Out of the north disaster shall be let loose upon all the inhabitants of the land.

For behold, I am calling all the tribes of the kingdoms of the north, declares the Lord,*s and they shall come, and every one shall set his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem, against all its walls all around and against all the cities of Judah.
And I will declare my judgments against them, for all their evil in forsaking me. They have made offerings to other gods and worshiped the works of their own hands.
But you, dress yourself for work; arise, and say to them everything that I command you. Do not be dismayed by them, lest I dismay you before them.
And I, behold, I make you this day a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls, against the whole land, against the kings of Judah, its officials, its priests, and the people of the land.
They will fight against you, but they shall not prevail against you, for I am with you, declares the Lord,*s to deliver you.”
Jeremiah 2
Israel Forsakes the Lord
The*p word of the Lord*s came to me, saying,

“Go and proclaim in the hearing of Jerusalem, Thus says the Lord,*s “I*pn remember the devotion of your youth, your*ld love as a bride, how*ln you followed me in the wilderness, in*ld a land not sown.
Israel*ln was holy to the Lord,*s the*ld firstfruits of his harvest. All*ln who ate of it incurred guilt; disaster*ld came upon them, declares*l the Lord.”*s
Hear*p the word of the Lord,*s O house of Jacob, and all the clans of the house of Israel.
Thus says the Lord:*s “What*pn wrong did your fathers find in me that*ld they went far from me, and*ln went after worthlessness, and became worthless?

They*ln did not say, ‘Where is the Lord*s who*ld brought us up from the land of Egypt, who*ln led us in the wilderness, in*ld a land of deserts and pits, in*ln a land of drought and deep darkness, in*ld a land that none passes through, where*ld no man dwells?’
And*ln I brought you into a plentiful land to*ld enjoy its fruits and its good things. But*ln when you came in, you defiled my land and*ld made my heritage an abomination.

The*ln priests did not say, ‘Where is the Lord?’*s Those*ld who handle the law did not know me; the*ln shepherds transgressed against me; the*ld prophets prophesied by Baal and*ld went after things that do not profit.
“Therefore*pn I still contend with you, declares*l the Lord,*s and*ld with your children’s children I will contend.
For*ln cross to the coasts of Cyprus and see, or*ld send to Kedar and examine with care; see*ld if there has been such a thing.
Has*ln a nation changed its gods, even*ld though they are no gods? But*ln my people have changed their glory for*ld that which does not profit.
Be*ln appalled, O heavens, at this; be*ld shocked, be utterly desolate, declares*l the Lord,*s
for*ln my people have committed two evils: they*ln have forsaken me, the*ld fountain of living waters, and*ln hewed out cisterns for themselves, broken*ld cisterns that can hold no water.
“Is*pn Israel a slave? Is he a homeborn servant? Why*ld then has he become a prey?
The*ln lions have roared against him; they*ld have roared loudly. They*ln have made his land a waste; his*ld cities are in ruins, without inhabitant.
Moreover,*ln the men of Memphis and Tahpanhes have*ld shaved the crown of your head.
Have*ln you not brought this upon yourself by*ld forsaking the Lord*s your God, when*ld he led you in the way?
And*ln now what do you gain by going to Egypt to*ld drink the waters of the Nile? Or*ln what do you gain by going to Assyria to*ld drink the waters of the Euphrates?

Your*ln evil will chastise you, and*ld your apostasy will reprove you. Know*ln and see that it is evil and bitter for*ld you to forsake the Lord*s your God; the*ld fear of me is not in you, declares*l the Lord God*s of hosts.
“For*pn long ago I broke your yoke and*ld burst your bonds; but*ld you said, ‘I will not serve.’ Yes,*ln on every high hill and*ld under every green tree you*ld bowed down like a whore.
Yet*ln I planted you a choice vine, wholly*ld of pure seed. How*ln then have you turned degenerate and*ld become a wild vine?
Though*ln you wash yourself with lye and*ld use much soap, the*ld stain of your guilt is still before me, declares*l the Lord God.*s
How*ln can you say, ‘I am not unclean, I*ld have not gone after the Baals’? Look*ln at your way in the valley; know*ld what you have done— a*ln restless young camel running here and there,
a*ld wild donkey used to the wilderness, in*ln her heat sniffing the wind! Who*ld can restrain her lust? None*ln who seek her need weary themselves; in*ld her month they will find her.
Keep*ln your feet from going unshod and*ld your throat from thirst. But*ln you said, ‘It is hopeless, for*ld I have loved foreigners, and*ld after them I will go.’
“As*pn a thief is shamed when caught, so*ld the house of Israel shall be shamed: they,*ln their kings, their officials, their*ld priests, and their prophets,

who*ln say to a tree, ‘You are my father,’ and*ld to a stone, ‘You gave me birth.’ For*ln they have turned their back to me, and*ld not their face. But*ln in the time of their trouble they say, ‘Arise*ld and save us!’
But*ln where are your gods that*ld you made for yourself? Let*ln them arise, if they can save you, in*ld your time of trouble; for*ln as many as your cities are*ld your gods, O Judah.
“Why*pn do you contend with me? You*ld have all transgressed against me, declares*l the Lord.*s
In*ln vain have I struck your children; they*ld took no correction; your*ln own sword devoured your prophets like*ld a ravening lion.

And*ln you, O generation, behold the word of the Lord.*s Have*ln I been a wilderness to Israel, or*ld a land of thick darkness? Why*ln then do my people say, ‘We are free, we*ld will come no more to you’?
Can*ln a virgin forget her ornaments, or*ld a bride her attire? Yet*ln my people have forgotten me days*ld without number.
“How*pn well you direct your course to*ld seek love! So*ln that even to wicked women you*ld have taught your ways.
Also*ln on your skirts is found the*ld lifeblood of the guiltless poor; you*ln did not find them breaking in. Yet*ld in spite of all these things
you*ln say, ‘I am innocent; surely*ld his anger has turned from me.’ Behold,*ln I will bring you to judgment for*ld saying, ‘I have not sinned.’
How*ln much you go about, changing*ld your way! You*ln shall be put to shame by Egypt as*ld you were put to shame by Assyria.
From*ln it too you will come away with*ld your hands on your head, for*ln the Lord*s has rejected those in whom you trust, and*ld you will not prosper by them.
Jeremiah 3

“If*pn a man divorces his wife and*ld she goes from him and*ln becomes another man’s wife, will*ld he return to her? Would*ln not that land be greatly polluted? You*ln have played the whore with many lovers; and*ld would you return to me? declares*l the Lord.*s

Lift*ln up your eyes to the bare heights, and see! Where*ld have you not been ravished? By*ln the waysides you have sat awaiting lovers like*ld an Arab in the wilderness. You*ln have polluted the land with*ld your vile whoredom.
Therefore*ln the showers have been withheld, and*ld the spring rain has not come; yet*ln you have the forehead of a whore; you*ld refuse to be ashamed.
Have*ln you not just now called to me, ‘My*ld father, you are the friend of my youth—
will*ln he be angry forever, will*ld he be indignant to the end?’ Behold,*ln you have spoken, but*ld you have done all the evil that you could.”
Faithless Israel Called to Repentance
The*p Lord*s said to me in the days of King Josiah: “Have you seen what she did, that faithless one, Israel, how she went up on every high hill and under every green tree, and there played the whore?
And I thought, ‘After she has done all this she will return to me,’ but she did not return, and her treacherous sister Judah saw it.
She saw that for all the adulteries of that faithless one, Israel, I had sent her away with a decree of divorce. Yet her treacherous sister Judah did not fear, but she too went and played the whore.
Because she took her whoredom lightly, she polluted the land, committing adultery with stone and tree.
Yet for all this her treacherous sister Judah did not return to me with her whole heart, but in pretense, declares the Lord.”*s
And*p the Lord*s said to me, “Faithless Israel has shown herself more righteous than treacherous Judah.

Go, and proclaim these words toward the north, and say, “‘Return,*pn faithless Israel, declares*l the Lord.*s I*ln will not look on you in anger, for*ld I am merciful, declares*l the Lord;*s I*ln will not be angry forever.

Only*ln acknowledge your guilt, that*ld you rebelled against the Lord*s your God and*ln scattered your favors among foreigners under every green tree, and*ld that you have not obeyed my voice, declares*l the Lord.*s
Return,*ln O faithless children, declares*l the Lord;*s for*ld I am your master; I*ln will take you, one from a city and two from a family, and*ld I will bring you to Zion.
“‘And*p I will give you shepherds after my own heart, who will feed you with knowledge and understanding.

And when you have multiplied and been fruitful in the land, in those days, declares the Lord,*s they shall no more say, “The ark of the covenant of the Lord.”*s It shall not come to mind or be remembered or missed; it shall not be made again.

At that time Jerusalem shall be called the throne of the Lord,*s and all nations shall gather to it, to the presence of the Lord*s in Jerusalem, and they shall no more stubbornly follow their own evil heart.
In those days the house of Judah shall join the house of Israel, and together they shall come from the land of the north to the land that I gave your fathers for a heritage.

“‘I*pn said, How*ld I would set you among my sons, and*ln give you a pleasant land, a*ld heritage most beautiful of all nations. And*ln I thought you would call me, My Father, and*ld would not turn from following me.
Surely,*ln as a treacherous wife leaves her husband, so*ld have you been treacherous to me, O house of Israel, declares*l the Lord.’”*s
A*pn voice on the bare heights is heard, the*ld weeping and pleading of Israel’s sons because*ln they have perverted their way; they*ld have forgotten the Lord*s their God.
“Return,*ln O faithless sons; I*ld will heal your faithlessness.” “Behold,*ln we come to you, for*ld you are the Lord*s our God.
Truly*ln the hills are a delusion, the*ld orgies on the mountains. Truly*ln in the Lord*s our God is*ld the salvation of Israel.
“But*p from our youth the shameful thing has devoured all for which our fathers labored, their flocks and their herds, their sons and their daughters.

Let us lie down in our shame, and let our dishonor cover us. For we have sinned against the Lord*s our God, we and our fathers, from our youth even to this day, and we have not obeyed the voice of the Lord*s our God.”
Jeremiah 4
“If*pn you return, O Israel, declares*l the Lord,*s to*ld me you should return. If*ln you remove your detestable things from my presence, and*ld do not waver,
and*ln if you swear, ‘As the Lord*s lives,’ in*ld truth, in justice, and in righteousness, then*ln nations shall bless themselves in him, and*ld in him shall they glory.”
For*p thus says the Lord*s to the men of Judah and Jerusalem: “Break*pn up your fallow ground, and*ld sow not among thorns.

Circumcise*ln yourselves to the Lord;*s remove*ld the foreskin of your hearts, O*ld men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem; lest*ln my wrath go forth like fire, and*ld burn with none to quench it, because*ld of the evil of your deeds.”
Disaster from the North
Declare*p in Judah, and proclaim in Jerusalem, and say, “Blow*pn the trumpet through the land; cry*ld aloud and say, ‘Assemble,*ln and let us go into*ld the fortified cities!’
Raise*ln a standard toward Zion, flee*ld for safety, stay not, for*ln I bring disaster from the north, and*ld great destruction.
A*ln lion has gone up from his thicket, a*ld destroyer of nations has set out; he*ld has gone out from his place to*ln make your land a waste; your*ld cities will be ruins without*ld inhabitant.
For*ln this put on sackcloth, lament*ld and wail, for*ln the fierce anger of the Lord*s has*ld not turned back from us.”
“In*p that day, declares the Lord,*s courage shall fail both king and officials. The priests shall be appalled and the prophets astounded.”
Then I said, “Ah, Lord God,*s surely you have utterly deceived this people and Jerusalem, saying, ‘It shall be well with you,’ whereas the sword has reached their very life.”
At*p that time it will be said to this people and to Jerusalem, “A hot wind from the bare heights in the desert toward the daughter of my people, not to winnow or cleanse,
a wind too full for this comes for me. Now it is I who speak in judgment upon them.”
Behold,*pn he comes up like clouds; his*ld chariots like the whirlwind; his*ln horses are swifter than eagles— woe*ld to us, for we are ruined!
O*ln Jerusalem, wash your heart from evil, that*ld you may be saved. How*ln long shall your wicked thoughts lodge*ld within you?
For*ln a voice declares from Dan and*ld proclaims trouble from Mount Ephraim.
Warn*ln the nations that he is coming; announce*ld to Jerusalem, “Besiegers*ln come from a distant land; they*ld shout against the cities of Judah.
Like*ln keepers of a field are they against her all around, because*ld she has rebelled against me, declares*l the Lord.*s
Your*ln ways and your deeds have*ld brought this upon you. This*ln is your doom, and it is bitter; it*ld has reached your very heart.”
Anguish over Judah’s Desolation
My*pn anguish, my anguish! I writhe in pain! Oh*ld the walls of my heart! My*ln heart is beating wildly; I*ld cannot keep silent, for*ln I hear the sound of the trumpet, the*ld alarm of war.
Crash*ln follows hard on crash; the*ld whole land is laid waste. Suddenly*ln my tents are laid waste, my*ld curtains in a moment.
How*ln long must I see the standard and*ld hear the sound of the trumpet?
“For*pn my people are foolish; they*ld know me not; they*ln are stupid children; they*ld have no understanding. They*ln are ‘wise’— in doing evil! But*ld how to do good they know not.”
I*pn looked on the earth, and behold, it was without form and void; and*ld to the heavens, and they had no light.
I*ln looked on the mountains, and behold, they were quaking, and*ld all the hills moved to and fro.
I*ln looked, and behold, there was no man, and*ld all the birds of the air had fled.
I*ln looked, and behold, the fruitful land was a desert, and*ld all its cities were laid in ruins before*ld the Lord,*s before his fierce anger.
For*p thus says the Lord,*s “The whole land shall be a desolation; yet I will not make a full end.
“For*pn this the earth shall mourn, and*ld the heavens above be dark; for*ln I have spoken; I have purposed; I*ld have not relented, nor will I turn back.”
At*pn the noise of horseman and archer every*ld city takes to flight; they*ln enter thickets; they climb among rocks; all*ld the cities are forsaken, and*ld no man dwells in them.

And*ln you, O desolate one, what*ln do you mean that you dress in scarlet, that*ld you adorn yourself with ornaments of gold, that*ld you enlarge your eyes with paint? In*ln vain you beautify yourself. Your*ld lovers despise you; they*ld seek your life.

For*ln I heard a cry as of a woman in labor, anguish*ld as of one giving birth to her first child, the*ln cry of the daughter of Zion gasping for breath, stretching*ld out her hands, “Woe*ln is me! I am fainting before murderers.”
Jeremiah 5
Jerusalem Refused to Repent
Run*pn to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem, look*ld and take note! Search*ln her squares to see if*ld you can find a man, one*ln who does justice and*ld seeks truth, that*ln I may pardon her.
Though*ln they say, “As the Lord*s lives,” yet*ld they swear falsely.

O*ln Lord,*s do not your eyes look for truth? You*ln have struck them down, but*ld they felt no anguish; you*ln have consumed them, but*ld they refused to take correction. They*ln have made their faces harder than rock; they*ld have refused to repent.
Then*pn I said, “These are only the poor; they*ld have no sense; for*ln they do not know the way of the Lord,*s the*ld justice of their God.
I*ln will go to the great and*ld will speak to them, for*ln they know the way of the Lord,*s the*ld justice of their God.” But*ln they all alike had broken the yoke; they*ld had burst the bonds.

Therefore*pn a lion from the forest shall strike them down; a*ld wolf from the desert shall devastate them. A*ln leopard is watching their cities; everyone*ld who goes out of them shall be torn in pieces, because*ln their transgressions are many, their*ld apostasies are great.

“How*pn can I pardon you? Your*ld children have forsaken me and*ld have sworn by those who are no gods. When*ln I fed them to the full, they*ld committed adultery and*ld trooped to the houses of whores.
They*ln were well-fed, lusty stallions, each*ld neighing for his neighbor’s wife.
Shall*ln I not punish them for these things? declares*l the Lord;*s and*ld shall I not avenge myself on*ld a nation such as this?
“Go*pn up through her vine rows and destroy, but*ld make not a full end; strip*ln away her branches, for*ld they are not the Lord’s.*s
For*ln the house of Israel and the house of Judah have*ld been utterly treacherous to me, declares*l the Lord.*s
They*ln have spoken falsely of the Lord*s and*ld have said, ‘He will do nothing; no*ln disaster will come upon us, nor*ld shall we see sword or famine.
The*ln prophets will become wind; the*ld word is not in them. Thus*ln shall it be done to them!’”
The Lord Proclaims Judgment

Therefore*pn thus says the Lord,*s the God of hosts: “Because*ln you have spoken this word, behold,*ln I am making my words in your mouth a fire, and*ld this people wood, and the fire shall consume them.

Behold,*ln I am bringing against you a*ld nation from afar, O house of Israel, declares*l the Lord.*s It*ln is an enduring nation; it*ld is an ancient nation, a*ln nation whose language you do not know, nor*ld can you understand what they say.

They*ln shall eat up your harvest and your food; they*ld shall eat up your sons and your daughters; they*ln shall eat up your flocks and your herds; they*ld shall eat up your vines and your fig trees; your*ln fortified cities in which you trust they*ld shall beat down with the sword.”
“But*p even in those days, declares the Lord,*s I will not make a full end of you.

And when your people say, ‘Why has the Lord*s our God done all these things to us?’ you shall say to them, ‘As you have forsaken me and served foreign gods in your land, so you shall serve foreigners in a land that is not yours.’”
Declare*pn this in the house of Jacob; proclaim*ld it in Judah:
“Hear*ln this, O foolish and senseless people, who*ld have eyes, but see not, who*ld have ears, but hear not.

Do*ln you not fear me? declares the Lord.*s Do*ld you not tremble before me? I*ln placed the sand as the boundary for the sea, a*ld perpetual barrier that it cannot pass; though*ln the waves toss, they cannot prevail; though*ld they roar, they cannot pass over it.
But*ln this people has a stubborn and rebellious heart; they*ld have turned aside and gone away.

They*ln do not say in their hearts, ‘Let*ld us fear the Lord*s our God, who*ln gives the rain in its season, the*ld autumn rain and the spring rain, and*ln keeps for us the*ld weeks appointed for the harvest.’
Your*ln iniquities have turned these away, and*ld your sins have kept good from you.
For*ln wicked men are found among my people; they*ld lurk like fowlers lying in wait. They*ln set a trap; they*ld catch men.
Like*ln a cage full of birds, their*ld houses are full of deceit; therefore*ln they have become great and rich;

they*ld have grown fat and sleek. They*ln know no bounds in deeds of evil; they*ld judge not with justice the*ln cause of the fatherless, to make it prosper, and*ld they do not defend the rights of the needy.
Shall*ln I not punish them for these things? declares*l the Lord,*s and*ld shall I not avenge myself on*ld a nation such as this?”
An*pn appalling and horrible thing has*ld happened in the land:
the*ln prophets prophesy falsely, and*ld the priests rule at their direction; my*ln people love to have it so, but*ld what will you do when the end comes?
Jeremiah 6
Impending Disaster for Jerusalem

Flee*pn for safety, O people of Benjamin, from*ld the midst of Jerusalem! Blow*ln the trumpet in Tekoa, and*ld raise a signal on Beth-haccherem, for*ln disaster looms out of the north, and*ld great destruction.
The*ln lovely and delicately bred I will destroy, the*ld daughter of Zion.
Shepherds*ln with their flocks shall come against her; they*ld shall pitch their tents around her; they*ld shall pasture, each in his place.
“Prepare*ln war against her; arise,*ld and let us attack at noon! Woe*ln to us, for the day declines, for*ld the shadows of evening lengthen!
Arise,*ln and let us attack by night and*ld destroy her palaces!”
For*pn thus says the Lord*s of hosts: “Cut*ln down her trees; cast*ld up a siege mound against Jerusalem. This*ln is the city that must be punished; there*ld is nothing but oppression within her.
As*ln a well keeps its water fresh, so*ld she keeps fresh her evil; violence*ln and destruction are heard within her; sickness*ld and wounds are ever before me.
Be*ln warned, O Jerusalem, lest*ld I turn from you in disgust, lest*ln I make you a desolation, an*ld uninhabited land.”
Thus*pn says the Lord*s of hosts: “They*ln shall glean thoroughly as a vine the*ld remnant of Israel; like*ln a grape gatherer pass your hand again over*ld its branches.”

To*ln whom shall I speak and give warning, that*ld they may hear? Behold,*ln their ears are uncircumcised, they*ld cannot listen; behold,*ln the word of the Lord*s is to them an object of scorn; they*ld take no pleasure in it.

Therefore*ln I am full of the wrath of the Lord;*s I*ld am weary of holding it in. “Pour*ln it out upon the children in the street, and*ld upon the gatherings of young men, also; both*ln husband and wife shall be taken, the*ld elderly and the very aged.
Their*ln houses shall be turned over to others, their*ld fields and wives together, for*ln I will stretch out my hand against*ld the inhabitants of the land,” declares*l the Lord.*s
“For*ln from the least to the greatest of them, everyone*ld is greedy for unjust gain; and*ln from prophet to priest, everyone*ld deals falsely.
They*ln have healed the wound of my people lightly, saying,*ld ‘Peace, peace,’ when*ld there is no peace.

Were*ln they ashamed when they committed abomination? No,*ld they were not at all ashamed; they*ld did not know how to blush. Therefore*ln they shall fall among those who fall; at*ld the time that I punish them, they shall be overthrown,” says*l the Lord.*s

Thus*pn says the Lord:*s “Stand*ln by the roads, and look, and*ld ask for the ancient paths, where*ln the good way is; and walk in it, and*ld find rest for your souls. But*ln they said, ‘We will not walk in it.’
I*ln set watchmen over you, saying, ‘Pay*ld attention to the sound of the trumpet!’ But*ln they said, ‘We will not pay attention.’
Therefore*ln hear, O nations, and*ld know, O congregation, what will happen to them.
Hear,*ln O earth; behold, I am bringing disaster upon this people, the*ld fruit of their devices, because*ln they have not paid attention to my words; and*ld as for my law, they have rejected it.
What*ln use to me is frankincense that comes from Sheba, or*ld sweet cane from a distant land? Your*ln burnt offerings are not acceptable, nor*ld your sacrifices pleasing to me.
Therefore*ln thus says the Lord:*s ‘Behold,*ln I will lay before this people stumbling*ld blocks against which they shall stumble; fathers*ln and sons together, neighbor*ld and friend shall perish.’”
Thus*pn says the Lord:*s “Behold,*ln a people is coming from the north country, a*ld great nation is stirring from the farthest parts of the earth.

They*ln lay hold on bow and javelin; they*ld are cruel and have no mercy; the*ld sound of them is like the roaring sea; they*ln ride on horses, set*ld in array as a man for battle, against*ld you, O daughter of Zion!”
We*ln have heard the report of it; our*ld hands fall helpless; anguish*ln has taken hold of us, pain*ld as of a woman in labor.
Go*ln not out into the field, nor*ld walk on the road, for*ln the enemy has a sword; terror*ld is on every side.
O*ln daughter of my people, put on sackcloth, and*ld roll in ashes; make*ln mourning as for an only son, most*ld bitter lamentation, for*ln suddenly the destroyer will*ld come upon us.
“I*pn have made you a tester of metals among my people, that*ld you may know and test their ways.
They*ln are all stubbornly rebellious, going*ld about with slanders; they*ln are bronze and iron; all*ld of them act corruptly.
The*ln bellows blow fiercely; the*ld lead is consumed by the fire; in*ln vain the refining goes on, for*ld the wicked are not removed.
Rejected*ln silver they are called, for*ld the Lord*s has rejected them.”
Jeremiah 7
Evil in the Land
The*p word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord:*s
“Stand in the gate of the Lord’s*s house, and proclaim there this word, and say, Hear the word of the Lord,*s all you men of Judah who enter these gates to worship the Lord.*s
Thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: Amend your ways and your deeds, and I will let you dwell in this place.
Do not trust in these deceptive words: ‘This is the temple of the Lord,*s the temple of the Lord,*s the temple of the Lord.’*s
“For*p if you truly amend your ways and your deeds, if you truly execute justice one with another,
if you do not oppress the sojourner, the fatherless, or the widow, or shed innocent blood in this place, and if you do not go after other gods to your own harm,
then I will let you dwell in this place, in the land that I gave of old to your fathers forever.
“Behold,*p you trust in deceptive words to no avail.
Will you steal, murder, commit adultery, swear falsely, make offerings to Baal, and go after other gods that you have not known,
and then come and stand before me in this house, which is called by my name, and say, ‘We are delivered!’— only to go on doing all these abominations?
Has this house, which is called by my name, become a den of robbers in your eyes? Behold, I myself have seen it, declares the Lord.*s
Go now to my place that was in Shiloh, where I made my name dwell at first, and see what I did to it because of the evil of my people Israel.
And now, because you have done all these things, declares the Lord,*s and when I spoke to you persistently you did not listen, and when I called you, you did not answer,
therefore I will do to the house that is called by my name, and in which you trust, and to the place that I gave to you and to your fathers, as I did to Shiloh.

Now*p after the king had burned the scroll with the words that Baruch wrote at Jeremiah’s dictation, the word of the Lord*s came to Jeremiah:
“Take another scroll and write on it all the former words that were in the first scroll, which Jehoiakim the king of Judah has burned.

And concerning Jehoiakim king of Judah you shall say, ‘Thus says the Lord,*s You have burned this scroll, saying, “Why have you written in it that the king of Babylon will certainly come and destroy this land, and will cut off from it man and beast?”
Therefore thus says the Lord*s concerning Jehoiakim king of Judah: He shall have none to sit on the throne of David, and his dead body shall be cast out to the heat by day and the frost by night.

And I will punish him and his offspring and his servants for their iniquity. I will bring upon them and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem and upon the people of Judah all the disaster that I have pronounced against them, but they would not hear.’”

Then*p Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to Baruch the scribe, the son of Neriah, who wrote on it at the dictation of Jeremiah all the words of the scroll that Jehoiakim king of Judah had burned in the fire. And many similar words were added to them.
Jeremiah 37
Jeremiah Warns Zedekiah
Zedekiah*p the son of Josiah, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon made king in the land of Judah, reigned instead of Coniah the son of Jehoiakim.
But neither he nor his servants nor the people of the land listened to the words of the Lord*s that he spoke through Jeremiah the prophet.
King*p Zedekiah sent Jehucal the son of Shelemiah, and Zephaniah the priest, the son of Maaseiah, to Jeremiah the prophet, saying, “Please pray for us to the Lord*s our God.”
Now Jeremiah was still going in and out among the people, for he had not yet been put in prison.
The army of Pharaoh had come out of Egypt. And when the Chaldeans who were besieging Jerusalem heard news about them, they withdrew from Jerusalem.
Then*p the word of the Lord*s came to Jeremiah the prophet:

“Thus says the Lord,*s God of Israel: Thus shall you say to the king of Judah who sent you to me to inquire of me, ‘Behold, Pharaoh’s army that came to help you is about to return to Egypt, to its own land.
And the Chaldeans shall come back and fight against this city. They shall capture it and burn it with fire.
Thus says the Lord,*s Do not deceive yourselves, saying, “The Chaldeans will surely go away from us,” for they will not go away.

For even if you should defeat the whole army of Chaldeans who are fighting against you, and there remained of them only wounded men, every man in his tent, they would rise up and burn this city with fire.’”
Jeremiah Imprisoned
Now*p when the Chaldean army had withdrawn from Jerusalem at the approach of Pharaoh’s army,
Jeremiah set out from Jerusalem to go to the land of Benjamin to receive his portion there among the people.
When he was at the Benjamin Gate, a sentry there named Irijah the son of Shelemiah, son of Hananiah, seized Jeremiah the prophet, saying, “You are deserting to the Chaldeans.”
And Jeremiah said, “It is a lie; I am not deserting to the Chaldeans.” But Irijah would not listen to him, and seized Jeremiah and brought him to the officials.
And the officials were enraged at Jeremiah, and they beat him and imprisoned him in the house of Jonathan the secretary, for it had been made a prison.
When*p Jeremiah had come to the dungeon cells and remained there many days,

King Zedekiah sent for him and received him. The king questioned him secretly in his house and said, “Is there any word from the Lord?”*s Jeremiah said, “There is.” Then he said, “You shall be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon.”
Jeremiah also said to King Zedekiah, “What wrong have I done to you or your servants or this people, that you have put me in prison?
Where are your prophets who prophesied to you, saying, ‘The king of Babylon will not come against you and against this land’?
Now hear, please, O my lord the king: let my humble plea come before you and do not send me back to the house of Jonathan the secretary, lest I die there.”

So King Zedekiah gave orders, and they committed Jeremiah to the court of the guard. And a loaf of bread was given him daily from the bakers’ street, until all the bread of the city was gone. So Jeremiah remained in the court of the guard.
Jeremiah 38
Jeremiah Cast into the Cistern
Now*p Shephatiah the son of Mattan, Gedaliah the son of Pashhur, Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur the son of Malchiah heard the words that Jeremiah was saying to all the people:

“Thus says the Lord:*s He who stays in this city shall die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence, but he who goes out to the Chaldeans shall live. He shall have his life as a prize of war, and live.
Thus says the Lord:*s This city shall surely be given into the hand of the army of the king of Babylon and be taken.”

Then the officials said to the king, “Let this man be put to death, for he is weakening the hands of the soldiers who are left in this city, and the hands of all the people, by speaking such words to them. For this man is not seeking the welfare of this people, but their harm.”
King Zedekiah said, “Behold, he is in your hands, for the king can do nothing against you.”

So they took Jeremiah and cast him into the cistern of Malchiah, the king’s son, which was in the court of the guard, letting Jeremiah down by ropes. And there was no water in the cistern, but only mud, and Jeremiah sank in the mud.
Jeremiah Rescued from the Cistern
When*p Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, a eunuch who was in the king’s house, heard that they had put Jeremiah into the cistern— the king was sitting in the Benjamin Gate—
Ebed-melech went from the king’s house and said to the king,
“My lord the king, these men have done evil in all that they did to Jeremiah the prophet by casting him into the cistern, and he will die there of hunger, for there is no bread left in the city.”
Then the king commanded Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, “Take thirty men with you from here, and lift Jeremiah the prophet out of the cistern before he dies.”

So Ebed-melech took the men with him and went to the house of the king, to a wardrobe in the storehouse, and took from there old rags and worn-out clothes, which he let down to Jeremiah in the cistern by ropes.
Then Ebed-melech the Ethiopian said to Jeremiah, “Put the rags and clothes between your armpits and the ropes.” Jeremiah did so.
Then they drew Jeremiah up with ropes and lifted him out of the cistern. And Jeremiah remained in the court of the guard.
Jeremiah Warns Zedekiah Again
King*p Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah the prophet and received him at the third entrance of the temple of the Lord.*s The king said to Jeremiah, “I will ask you a question; hide nothing from me.”
Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “If I tell you, will you not surely put me to death? And if I give you counsel, you will not listen to me.”
Then King Zedekiah swore secretly to Jeremiah, “As the Lord*s lives, who made our souls, I will not put you to death or deliver you into the hand of these men who seek your life.”

Then*p Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “Thus says the Lord,*s the God of hosts, the God of Israel: If you will surrender to the officials of the king of Babylon, then your life shall be spared, and this city shall not be burned with fire, and you and your house shall live.

But if you do not surrender to the officials of the king of Babylon, then this city shall be given into the hand of the Chaldeans, and they shall burn it with fire, and you shall not escape from their hand.”
King Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “I am afraid of the Judeans who have deserted to the Chaldeans, lest I be handed over to them and they deal cruelly with me.”
Jeremiah said, “You shall not be given to them. Obey now the voice of the Lord*s in what I say to you, and it shall be well with you, and your life shall be spared.
But if you refuse to surrender, this is the vision which the Lord*s has shown to me:

Behold, all the women left in the house of the king of Judah were being led out to the officials of the king of Babylon and were saying, “‘Your*pn trusted friends have deceived you and*ld prevailed against you; now*ln that your feet are sunk in the mud, they*ld turn away from you.’

All*p your wives and your sons shall be led out to the Chaldeans, and you yourself shall not escape from their hand, but shall be seized by the king of Babylon, and this city shall be burned with fire.”
Then*p Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “Let no one know of these words, and you shall not die.

If the officials hear that I have spoken with you and come to you and say to you, ‘Tell us what you said to the king and what the king said to you; hide nothing from us and we will not put you to death,’
then you shall say to them, ‘I made a humble plea to the king that he would not send me back to the house of Jonathan to die there.’”
Then all the officials came to Jeremiah and asked him, and he answered them as the king had instructed him. So they stopped speaking with him, for the conversation had not been overheard.
And Jeremiah remained in the court of the guard until the day that Jerusalem was taken.
Jeremiah 39
The Fall of Jerusalem
In*p the ninth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, in the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and all his army came against Jerusalem and besieged it.
In the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, on the ninth day of the month, a breach was made in the city.

Then all the officials of the king of Babylon came and sat in the middle gate: Nergal-sar-ezer of Samgar, Nebu-sar-sekim the Rab-saris, Nergal-sar-ezer the Rab-mag, with all the rest of the officers of the king of Babylon.

When Zedekiah king of Judah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled, going out of the city at night by way of the king’s garden through the gate between the two walls; and they went toward the Arabah.

But the army of the Chaldeans pursued them and overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho. And when they had taken him, they brought him up to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, at Riblah, in the land of Hamath; and he passed sentence on him.
The king of Babylon slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah at Riblah before his eyes, and the king of Babylon slaughtered all the nobles of Judah.
He put out the eyes of Zedekiah and bound him in chains to take him to Babylon.
The Chaldeans burned the king’s house and the house of the people, and broke down the walls of Jerusalem.
Then Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, carried into exile to Babylon the rest of the people who were left in the city, those who had deserted to him, and the people who remained.
Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, left in the land of Judah some of the poor people who owned nothing, and gave them vineyards and fields at the same time.
The Lord Delivers Jeremiah
Nebuchadnezzar*p king of Babylon gave command concerning Jeremiah through Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, saying,
“Take him, look after him well, and do him no harm, but deal with him as he tells you.”
So Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard, Nebushazban the Rab-saris, Nergal-sar-ezer the Rab-mag, and all the chief officers of the king of Babylon
sent and took Jeremiah from the court of the guard. They entrusted him to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, that he should take him home. So he lived among the people.
The*p word of the Lord*s came to Jeremiah while he was shut up in the court of the guard:

“Go, and say to Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, ‘Thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: Behold, I will fulfill my words against this city for harm and not for good, and they shall be accomplished before you on that day.
But I will deliver you on that day, declares the Lord,*s and you shall not be given into the hand of the men of whom you are afraid.
For I will surely save you, and you shall not fall by the sword, but you shall have your life as a prize of war, because you have put your trust in me, declares the Lord.’”*s
Jeremiah 40
Jeremiah Remains in Judah

The*p word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord*s after Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had let him go from Ramah, when he took him bound in chains along with all the captives of Jerusalem and Judah who were being exiled to Babylon.
The captain of the guard took Jeremiah and said to him, “The Lord*s your God pronounced this disaster against this place.
The Lord*s has brought it about, and has done as he said. Because you sinned against the Lord*s and did not obey his voice, this thing has come upon you.

Now, behold, I release you today from the chains on your hands. If it seems good to you to come with me to Babylon, come, and I will look after you well, but if it seems wrong to you to come with me to Babylon, do not come. See, the whole land is before you; go wherever you think it good and right to go.

If you remain, then return to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon appointed governor of the cities of Judah, and dwell with him among the people. Or go wherever you think it right to go.” So the captain of the guard gave him an allowance of food and a present, and let him go.
Then Jeremiah went to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, at Mizpah, and lived with him among the people who were left in the land.

When*p all the captains of the forces in the open country and their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah the son of Ahikam governor in the land and had committed to him men, women, and children, those of the poorest of the land who had not been taken into exile to Babylon,

they went to Gedaliah at Mizpah— Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, Johanan the son of Kareah, Seraiah the son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, Jezaniah the son of the Maacathite, they and their men.

Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, swore to them and their men, saying, “Do not be afraid to serve the Chaldeans. Dwell in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it shall be well with you.

As for me, I will dwell at Mizpah, to represent you before the Chaldeans who will come to us. But as for you, gather wine and summer fruits and oil, and store them in your vessels, and dwell in your cities that you have taken.”

Likewise, when all the Judeans who were in Moab and among the Ammonites and in Edom and in other lands heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant in Judah and had appointed Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, as governor over them,
then all the Judeans returned from all the places to which they had been driven and came to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah at Mizpah. And they gathered wine and summer fruits in great abundance.
Now*p Johanan the son of Kareah and all the leaders of the forces in the open country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah
and said to him, “Do you know that Baalis the king of the Ammonites has sent Ishmael the son of Nethaniah to take your life?” But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam would not believe them.

Then Johanan the son of Kareah spoke secretly to Gedaliah at Mizpah, “Please let me go and strike down Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and no one will know it. Why should he take your life, so that all the Judeans who are gathered about you would be scattered, and the remnant of Judah would perish?”
But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam said to Johanan the son of Kareah, “You shall not do this thing, for you are speaking falsely of Ishmael.”
Jeremiah 41
Gedaliah Murdered

In*p the seventh month, Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of the royal family, one of the chief officers of the king, came with ten men to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, at Mizpah. As they ate bread together there at Mizpah,

Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and the ten men with him rose up and struck down Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, with the sword, and killed him, whom the king of Babylon had appointed governor in the land.
Ishmael also struck down all the Judeans who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah, and the Chaldean soldiers who happened to be there.
On*p the day after the murder of Gedaliah, before anyone knew of it,

eighty men arrived from Shechem and Shiloh and Samaria, with their beards shaved and their clothes torn, and their bodies gashed, bringing grain offerings and incense to present at the temple of the Lord.*s
And Ishmael the son of Nethaniah came out from Mizpah to meet them, weeping as he came. As he met them, he said to them, “Come in to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam.”
When they came into the city, Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and the men with him slaughtered them and cast them into a cistern.

But there were ten men among them who said to Ishmael, “Do not put us to death, for we have stores of wheat, barley, oil, and honey hidden in the fields.” So he refrained and did not put them to death with their companions.

Now*p the cistern into which Ishmael had thrown all the bodies of the men whom he had struck down along with Gedaliah was the large cistern that King Asa had made for defense against Baasha king of Israel; Ishmael the son of Nethaniah filled it with the slain.

Then Ishmael took captive all the rest of the people who were in Mizpah, the king’s daughters and all the people who were left at Mizpah, whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had committed to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam. Ishmael the son of Nethaniah took them captive and set out to cross over to the Ammonites.
But*p when Johanan the son of Kareah and all the leaders of the forces with him heard of all the evil that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had done,
they took all their men and went to fight against Ishmael the son of Nethaniah. They came upon him at the great pool that is in Gibeon.
And when all the people who were with Ishmael saw Johanan the son of Kareah and all the leaders of the forces with him, they rejoiced.
So all the people whom Ishmael had carried away captive from Mizpah turned around and came back, and went to Johanan the son of Kareah.
But Ishmael the son of Nethaniah escaped from Johanan with eight men, and went to the Ammonites.

Then Johanan the son of Kareah and all the leaders of the forces with him took from Mizpah all the rest of the people whom he had recovered from Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, after he had struck down Gedaliah the son of Ahikam— soldiers, women, children, and eunuchs, whom Johanan brought back from Gibeon.
And they went and stayed at Geruth Chimham near Bethlehem, intending to go to Egypt
because of the Chaldeans. For they were afraid of them, because Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had struck down Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, whom the king of Babylon had made governor over the land.
Jeremiah 42
Warning Against Going to Egypt
Then*p all the commanders of the forces, and Johanan the son of Kareah and Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah, and all the people from the least to the greatest, came near
and said to Jeremiah the prophet, “Let our plea for mercy come before you, and pray to the Lord*s your God for us, for all this remnant— because we are left with but a few, as your eyes see us—
that the Lord*s your God may show us the way we should go, and the thing that we should do.”

Jeremiah the prophet said to them, “I have heard you. Behold, I will pray to the Lord*s your God according to your request, and whatever the Lord*s answers you I will tell you. I will keep nothing back from you.”
Then they said to Jeremiah, “May the Lord*s be a true and faithful witness against us if we do not act according to all the word with which the Lord*s your God sends you to us.
Whether it is good or bad, we will obey the voice of the Lord*s our God to whom we are sending you, that it may be well with us when we obey the voice of the Lord*s our God.”
At*p the end of ten days the word of the Lord*s came to Jeremiah.
Then he summoned Johanan the son of Kareah and all the commanders of the forces who were with him, and all the people from the least to the greatest,
and said to them, “Thus says the Lord,*s the God of Israel, to whom you sent me to present your plea for mercy before him:
If you will remain in this land, then I will build you up and not pull you down; I will plant you, and not pluck you up; for I relent of the disaster that I did to you.
Do not fear the king of Babylon, of whom you are afraid. Do not fear him, declares the Lord,*s for I am with you, to save you and to deliver you from his hand.
I will grant you mercy, that he may have mercy on you and let you remain in your own land.
But if you say, ‘We will not remain in this land,’ disobeying the voice of the Lord*s your God
and saying, ‘No, we will go to the land of Egypt, where we shall not see war or hear the sound of the trumpet or be hungry for bread, and we will dwell there,’
then hear the word of the Lord,*s O remnant of Judah. Thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: If you set your faces to enter Egypt and go to live there,
then the sword that you fear shall overtake you there in the land of Egypt, and the famine of which you are afraid shall follow close after you to Egypt, and there you shall die.

All the men who set their faces to go to Egypt to live there shall die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence. They shall have no remnant or survivor from the disaster that I will bring upon them.

“For*p thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: As my anger and my wrath were poured out on the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so my wrath will be poured out on you when you go to Egypt. You shall become an execration, a horror, a curse, and a taunt. You shall see this place no more.
The Lord*s has said to you, O remnant of Judah, ‘Do not go to Egypt.’ Know for a certainty that I have warned you this day

that you have gone astray at the cost of your lives. For you sent me to the Lord*s your God, saying, ‘Pray for us to the Lord*s our God, and whatever the Lord*s our God says, declare to us and we will do it.’
And I have this day declared it to you, but you have not obeyed the voice of the Lord*s your God in anything that he sent me to tell you.
Now therefore know for a certainty that you shall die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence in the place where you desire to go to live.”
Jeremiah 43
Jeremiah Taken to Egypt
When*p Jeremiah finished speaking to all the people all these words of the Lord*s their God, with which the Lord*s their God had sent him to them,

Azariah the son of Hoshaiah and Johanan the son of Kareah and all the insolent men said to Jeremiah, “You are telling a lie. The Lord*s our God did not send you to say, ‘Do not go to Egypt to live there,’
but Baruch the son of Neriah has set you against us, to deliver us into the hand of the Chaldeans, that they may kill us or take us into exile in Babylon.”
So Johanan the son of Kareah and all the commanders of the forces and all the people did not obey the voice of the Lord,*s to remain in the land of Judah.
But Johanan the son of Kareah and all the commanders of the forces took all the remnant of Judah who had returned to live in the land of Judah from all the nations to which they had been driven—

the men, the women, the children, the princesses, and every person whom Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had left with Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan; also Jeremiah the prophet and Baruch the son of Neriah.
And they came into the land of Egypt, for they did not obey the voice of the Lord.*s And they arrived at Tahpanhes.
Then*p the word of the Lord*s came to Jeremiah in Tahpanhes:
“Take in your hands large stones and hide them in the mortar in the pavement that is at the entrance to Pharaoh’s palace in Tahpanhes, in the sight of the men of Judah,

and say to them, ‘Thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: Behold, I will send and take Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon, my servant, and I will set his throne above these stones that I have hidden, and he will spread his royal canopy over them.

He shall come and strike the land of Egypt, giving over to the pestilence those who are doomed to the pestilence, to captivity those who are doomed to captivity, and to the sword those who are doomed to the sword.

I shall kindle a fire in the temples of the gods of Egypt, and he shall burn them and carry them away captive. And he shall clean the land of Egypt as a shepherd cleans his cloak of vermin, and he shall go away from there in peace.
He shall break the obelisks of Heliopolis, which is in the land of Egypt, and the temples of the gods of Egypt he shall burn with fire.’”
Jeremiah 44
Judgment for Idolatry
The*p word that came to Jeremiah concerning all the Judeans who lived in the land of Egypt, at Migdol, at Tahpanhes, at Memphis, and in the land of Pathros,

“Thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: You have seen all the disaster that I brought upon Jerusalem and upon all the cities of Judah. Behold, this day they are a desolation, and no one dwells in them,
because of the evil that they committed, provoking me to anger, in that they went to make offerings and serve other gods that they knew not, neither they, nor you, nor your fathers.
Yet I persistently sent to you all my servants the prophets, saying, ‘Oh, do not do this abomination that I hate!’
But they did not listen or incline their ear, to turn from their evil and make no offerings to other gods.
Therefore my wrath and my anger were poured out and kindled in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem, and they became a waste and a desolation, as at this day.

And now thus says the Lord*s God of hosts, the God of Israel: Why do you commit this great evil against yourselves, to cut off from you man and woman, infant and child, from the midst of Judah, leaving you no remnant?

Why do you provoke me to anger with the works of your hands, making offerings to other gods in the land of Egypt where you have come to live, so that you may be cut off and become a curse and a taunt among all the nations of the earth?

Have you forgotten the evil of your fathers, the evil of the kings of Judah, the evil of their wives, your own evil, and the evil of your wives, which they committed in the land of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?
They have not humbled themselves even to this day, nor have they feared, nor walked in my law and my statutes that I set before you and before your fathers.
“Therefore*p thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: Behold, I will set my face against you for harm, to cut off all Judah.

I will take the remnant of Judah who have set their faces to come to the land of Egypt to live, and they shall all be consumed. In the land of Egypt they shall fall; by the sword and by famine they shall be consumed. From the least to the greatest, they shall die by the sword and by famine, and they shall become an oath, a horror, a curse, and a taunt.
I will punish those who dwell in the land of Egypt, as I have punished Jerusalem, with the sword, with famine, and with pestilence,

so that none of the remnant of Judah who have come to live in the land of Egypt shall escape or survive or return to the land of Judah, to which they desire to return to dwell there. For they shall not return, except some fugitives.”

Then*p all the men who knew that their wives had made offerings to other gods, and all the women who stood by, a great assembly, all the people who lived in Pathros in the land of Egypt, answered Jeremiah:
“As for the word that you have spoken to us in the name of the Lord,*s we will not listen to you.

But we will do everything that we have vowed, make offerings to the queen of heaven and pour out drink offerings to her, as we did, both we and our fathers, our kings and our officials, in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. For then we had plenty of food, and prospered, and saw no disaster.
But since we left off making offerings to the queen of heaven and pouring out drink offerings to her, we have lacked everything and have been consumed by the sword and by famine.”

And the women said, “When we made offerings to the queen of heaven and poured out drink offerings to her, was it without our husbands’ approval that we made cakes for her bearing her image and poured out drink offerings to her?”
Then*p Jeremiah said to all the people, men and women, all the people who had given him this answer:

“As for the offerings that you offered in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem, you and your fathers, your kings and your officials, and the people of the land, did not the Lord*s remember them? Did it not come into his mind?
The Lord*s could no longer bear your evil deeds and the abominations that you committed. Therefore your land has become a desolation and a waste and a curse, without inhabitant, as it is this day.

It is because you made offerings and because you sinned against the Lord*s and did not obey the voice of the Lord*s or walk in his law and in his statutes and in his testimonies that this disaster has happened to you, as at this day.”
Jeremiah*p said to all the people and all the women, “Hear the word of the Lord,*s all you of Judah who are in the land of Egypt.

Thus says the Lord*s of hosts, the God of Israel: You and your wives have declared with your mouths, and have fulfilled it with your hands, saying, ‘We will surely perform our vows that we have made, to make offerings to the queen of heaven and to pour out drink offerings to her.’ Then confirm your vows and perform your vows!

Therefore hear the word of the Lord,*s all you of Judah who dwell in the land of Egypt: Behold, I have sworn by my great name, says the Lord,*s that my name shall no more be invoked by the mouth of any man of Judah in all the land of Egypt, saying, ‘As the Lord God*s lives.’
Behold, I am watching over them for disaster and not for good. All the men of Judah who are in the land of Egypt shall be consumed by the sword and by famine, until there is an end of them.

And those who escape the sword shall return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah, few in number; and all the remnant of Judah, who came to the land of Egypt to live, shall know whose word will stand, mine or theirs.
This shall be the sign to you, declares the Lord,*s that I will punish you in this place, in order that you may know that my words will surely stand against you for harm:

Thus says the Lord,*s Behold, I will give Pharaoh Hophra king of Egypt into the hand of his enemies and into the hand of those who seek his life, as I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, who was his enemy and sought his life.”

The Fall of Jerusalem Recounted
Zedekiah*p was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.

So the city was besieged till the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
On the ninth day of the fourth month the famine was so severe in the city that there was no food for the people of the land.

Then a breach was made in the city, and all the men of war fled and went out from the city by night by the way of a gate between the two walls, by the king’s garden, and the Chaldeans were around the city. And they went in the direction of the Arabah.
